awd_titl_txt: Climate Conversations: Discursive Strategies of Climate Justice Organizing
awd_abstract_narration:
This award was provided as part of NSF’s Social, Behavioral and Economic Sciences Postdoctoral Research Fellowships (SPRF) program. The goal of the SPRF program is to prepare promising, early career doctoral-level scientists for scientific careers in academia, industry or private sector, and government. SPRF awards involve two years of training under the sponsorship of established scientists and encourage Postdoctoral Fellows to perform independent research. NSF seeks to promote the participation of scientists from all segments of the scientific community, including those from underrepresented groups, in its research programs and activities; the postdoctoral period is considered to be an important level of professional development in attaining this goal. Each Postdoctoral Fellow must address important scientific questions that advance their respective disciplinary fields. Under the sponsorship of Dr. Corrie Grosse at College of Saint Benedict and Saint John’s University, this postdoctoral fellowship award supports an early career scientist examining discursive strategies of climate justice organizing. Previous research on climate change communication has largely focused on non-interactive, monologic texts that aim to inform or persuade audiences, rather than on interactive, dialogic conversations about climate change. However, many grassroots climate communicators and organizations currently see such climate conversations as essential for shifting attitudes and inspiring action. The proposed study applies an interactional sociolinguistic approach to the analysis of climate conversations, with the aim of identifying effective discursive strategies for advancing climate justice within and across specific sociocultural contexts in the United States.

Through a participatory research framework that combines survey, interview, and discourse-analytic methods, the study will (a) examine how grassroots climate communicators employ climate conversations in their organizing and (b) identify characteristics of successful climate conversations, determining success through pre- and post-surveys of conversational participants’ climate-related actions and views. Through fine-grained analysis of interactional language use, this analysis will shed light on how slow-moving, intersectional crises such as climate change are managed in discourse. By prioritizing participation by marginalized climate justice organizers, such as Black and Indigenous organizers, this project will help to remedy the underrepresentation of these voices in previous research. The analysis of successful climate conversations will empower climate communicators to hone effective communicative strategies guided by scientific inquiry, helping to address the problem of low perceived efficacy, which has emerged as a barrier to climate action. Finally, the project will generate a corpus of climate conversations that will be of use to other researchers and climate change communication practitioners.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Having climate conversations can influence people?s attitudes and encourage action (Beery et al., 2019; Galway et al., 2021; Goldberg et al., 2019; Lawson et al., 2019). However, little is known about how climate conversations lead to these outcomes?a question that could help optimize conversational strategies, settings, and supporting trainings and resources (Ettinger et al., 2023). This project combines discourse analysis with survey methods to first gain insight into US climate activists? experiences with and recommendations for climate conversations, then examine the content and outcomes of climate conversations between activists and non-activists they know.

 

Phase 1: How do US climate activists have climate conversations?

 

In the first phase, 112 climate activists across the US were surveyed about their practices and beliefs surrounding climate conversations. Most activists said they had climate conversations at least several times per week, typically in small groups or one-on-one. Although activists considered it most important to target disengaged and uncertain audiences, they mostly spoke with people who were already concerned. Reasons for choosing like-minded audiences included avoiding hostility and focusing on marginalized communities. Activists noted barriers to engaging even concerned audiences, such as lack of time and energy, COVID-19, and not wanting to be burdensome.

 

Common conversational goals included communicating the seriousness of the climate crisis, raising awareness of climate solutions, promoting individual and collective action, and discussing climate justice. While only 9% of activists said that their past conversations were very effective at achieving their goals, 81% said they were at least somewhat effective. Their recommended conversational strategies included asking questions, listening, finding common ground, connecting to the audience?s interests and values, sharing personal stories, giving local and current examples, and offering concrete opportunities for collective action.

 

Phase 2: Can climate conversations lead to collective action?

 

In the second phase, 41 climate activists were asked to have a series of three climate conversations with their chosen conversational partner (someone they knew who was not involved in climate action). Activists mostly chose close friends and family members, most of whom were politically progressive. Over Zoom or in person, each pair spent an hour discussing the seriousness of the climate crisis, the viability of climate solutions, the need for climate justice, and opportunities for collective action. Three weeks later, they spent half an hour checking in on whether the conversational partner had been able to take action, and why or why not. They had an additional check-in conversation three weeks after that. All participants took one survey at the beginning of the study, then took a survey after each conversation. These surveys asked how the conversations went and measured conversational partners? knowledge, concern, intention to take climate action, and perceived ability to make a difference through action. Three months after the final conversation, conversational partners took a follow-up survey about their actions over the course of the study (five months). A control group of 41 non-activists who knew climate activists took near-identical surveys on the same timeline as the conversational partners. A second control group took only one survey about their actions over the past five months, providing a baseline. The conversations were audio- or video-recorded and qualitatively analyzed in ATLAS.ti.

 

Conversational partners? self-reported knowledge of climate issues increased significantly more than that of control group participants who only took surveys (p = 0.011), as did their intention to take action (p = 0.028). Their level of concern and perceived ability to make a difference did not increase significantly more. Surprisingly, conversational partners did not take significantly more collective action than control group participants. The most commonly mentioned barriers to action were lack of free time, having other concerns, not feeling able to make a difference, not knowing enough about collective climate action, and feeling psychologically distant from both climate impacts and climate action. To counter these barriers, activists explained types of collective climate action, shared success stories, connected collective climate action to their conversational partners? interests, and made direct suggestions and invitations. Activists? use of these conversational strategies was not significantly correlated with collective action?taking among conversational partners, likely because collective action was rare overall. However, activists? discussion of collective climate action?but not climate solutions in general?was correlated with an increase in partners? perceived ability to make a difference (rs(37): 0.39, p = 0.015). Feeling able to make a difference has been shown to predict collective action (Doherty & Webler, 2016; McCreary, 2017). Therefore, these findings suggest that, to mobilize concerned audiences, climate conversations should focus on specific, approachable, and compelling opportunities for collective action. Further iterative testing and refinement of climate conversations will help to hone context-specific best practices, trainings, and supporting resources.
